items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to strong winds, surge and high spring tides on the coast from tomorrow, Wednesday 21/08/2024 and over the coming days. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, including Hornsea. Flooding is possible between 5:45AM and 8AM tomorrow, Wednesday 21/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts / warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary from Liverpool and Wirral to Widnes

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024.    

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 01:00 AM on 21/08/2024 at the following location: 

Hale Village, peaking at 01:00am. 

We currently do not anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide around midday tomorrow. However, we are expecting the Flood Alert to be met during the early hours of Thursday and Friday. Flood Warnings may also be issued for these high tides.  

 Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.    

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.    

This message will be updated tomorrow or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message: A flood alert has been issued as a result of high tides, flooding is expected over the next 4 days with tides peaking Thursday evening 22/08/24. Conditions may apply for an hour either side of high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks today Tuesday evening 20/08/24:- Newport 7.0m to 7.3m at 20:45. Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.6m at 20:45.  No thresholds are expected to be crossed on Wednesday mornings tide but they are rising again for Wednesday evening.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please stay away from large waves as they are dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Wednesday, 21/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson, Conder Green, Conder Bridge and Thurnham Moss at 12:45 AM on 21/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near the coast.
Further flooding is possible on the overnight tide tomorrow, 21/08/2024 into Thursday 22/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Take care along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 21/08/2024.   

Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 01:00 AM on 21/08/2024 at the following locations:   

Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 01:00 AM  

Eastford Road, peaking around 01:30 AM   

Arpley Bridge and Knutsford Road, peaking around 01:45 AM  

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.      

We currently do not anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide around midday tomorrow. However, we are expecting the Flood Alert to be met during the early hours of the morning on Thursday and Friday. Flood Warnings may also be issued for these high tides. 

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation.   

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.   

This message will be updated tomorrow or as the situation changes

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the possibility of spray overtopping on the coast from early hours of tomorrow morning 21/08/2024. 

Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads from Hilbre Island and along the coast from West Kirby to Heswall from 01:00am 21/08/2024. No flooding to property is expected.  

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.  

Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated tomorrow or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This Flood Warning has been issued due strong winds, surge and high spring tides from tomorrow, Wednesday 21/08/2024 and over the coming days. Wave and spray overtopping is possible between 5:45AM and 8AM tomorrow, Wednesday 21/08/2024. This could cause some localised flooding. Areas most at risk of flooding include Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the coming days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 7PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to strong winds, surge and high spring tides on the coast from tomorrow, Wednesday 21/08/2024 and over the coming days. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads in the Spurn Road, Southfield Farm and Kilnsea Caravan park areas. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. Flooding is possible between 5:45AM and 9AM tomorrow, Wednesday 21/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: High spring tides are forecast over the coming days. First forecast high water is 20:45 BST on 20/08/2024 with a level of 7.40 mAOD and a Force 5 Westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not expected to flood at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Tomorrow morning’s tide is not forecast to reach flood alert thresholds. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by tomorrow, Wednesday 21st August 2024.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss at 12:45 AM on 21/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths.
Further flooding is possible on the overnight tide tomorrow, 21/08/2024 into Thursday 22/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Take care along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 07:15 and 09:15, Wednesday 21st August.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.  We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.51 mAODN at 08:15,  Wednesday 21st August,  which is 0.13m above tide tables,  wind Force 6,  in a westerly direction  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30 tomorrow, Wednesday 21st August.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 12:45 AM on 21/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths.
Further flooding is possible on the overnight tide tomorrow, 21/08/2024 into Thursday 22/08/2024 due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Take care along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 01:00 and 03:00, Wednesday 21st August.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.  Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.46 mAODN at 02:00,  Wednesday 21st August,  which is 0.22m above tide tables,  wind Force 5,  in a westerly direction  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30 tomorrow, Wednesday 21st August.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 07:15 and 09:15, Wednesday 21st August.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.  We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.51 mAODN at 08:15,  Wednesday 21st August,  which is 0.13m above tide tables,  wind Force 6,  in a westerly direction  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30 tomorrow, Wednesday 21st August.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening and tomorrow morning in response to high tides at Porlock Weir.

Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. No property flooding is expected.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Hinkley Point. The first forecast high water is at 8:30 PM on 20/08/2024 with a level of 6.41 mAODN with westerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 8:45 AM on 21/08/2024, with a level of 6.19 mAODN and south-westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This flood alert is expected to remain in force during this high tide sequence up to and including the high tide at 22:30 on 23/08/2024. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between a 00:30 and 02:30, Wednesday 21st August.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray.  The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.75 mAODN at 01:30,  Wednesday 21st August,  which is 0.12m above tide tables,  wind Force 6, in a westerly direction  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30 tomorrow, Wednesday 21st August.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this evening may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible around the high tide between 11:00 PM on 20/08/2024 and 3:30 AM on 21/08/2024. Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
Further flooding is possible on the overnight tide tomorrow, 21/08/2024 into Thursday, 22/08/2024, due to spring tides and strong winds over the next few days. We have closed flood gates at Arnside promenade, and these will remain closed throughout the high tide cycle. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to high tides and surge on the coast this afternoon, Tuesday 20/08/2024 and tomorrow morning, Wednesday 21/08/2024. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Flooding of coastal roads is possible between 5:30PM-9:30PM, this evening Tuesday 20/08/2024 and between 5:30AM-9:30AM, tomorrow morning, Wednesday 21/08/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11PM on Wednesday 21/08/2024, or as the situation changes.
